title: 114_hr2375
content: The "Student Support Act" is introduced, amending the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to focus on school-based mental health and student service providers. This includes the addition of a new chapter addressing findings related to school-based mental health and student services. The Congress acknowledges the lack of mental health treatment for children and adolescents, leading to costly consequences. There is a need for more school-based counseling professionals to provide crucial support services, as current resources are insufficient. The current national average ratio of students to school counselors in elementary and secondary schools is 471 to 1. Leading counseling, guidance, and mental health organizations recommend ratios of 250 to 1 for school counselors, 1,000 to 1 for school psychologists, and 250 to 1 for school social workers. United States schools need more mental health professionals to better serve students. The current national average ratio of students to school counselors is 471 to 1, with recommendations for ratios of 250 to 1 for school counselors, 1,000 to 1 for school psychologists, and 250 to 1 for school social workers. Some schools lack mental health professionals, leading to high student-to-professional ratios and a need for more professionals as student populations grow. Model programs using school-based mental health providers have shown positive outcomes in reducing disciplinary actions. Model programs using school-based mental health providers have shown positive outcomes in reducing disciplinary actions, such as reduced referrals to the principal's office, decreased use of weapons, force, and threats, and increased students' feelings of safety. "SEC. 5546. PURPOSES." The chapter aims to help States and local educational agencies hire more school-based mental health providers to reduce the ratios of providers to students in elementary and secondary schools in the United States. The recommended minimum ratio is one school counselor for every 250 students. The chapter recommends hiring more school-based mental health providers to reduce ratios in elementary and secondary schools in the United States. The suggested ratios include one school counselor for every 250 students, one school psychologist for every 1,000 students, and one school social worker for every 250 students. The goal is to provide mental health services, remove barriers to learning, support school staff, improve classroom management, involve parents in enhancing student behavior and academic success. "SEC. 5547. DEFINITIONS." In this chapter, key definitions include the age range for a "child," the meaning of a "child and adolescent psychiatrist," the definition of a "child in poverty," and the role of a "mental health and student service provider." The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms like "mental health and student services," "other qualified psychologist," and "poverty line." These definitions are important for understanding the roles and criteria in the education system. The curr_chunk defines "school counselor" as an individual with counseling competence in a school setting, holding state licensure, national certification, or a master's degree in school counseling. It also defines "school psychologist" as an individual with specific qualifications. The curr_chunk defines a "school social worker" as an individual with a master's degree in social work from an accredited program. A school social worker must have a master's degree in social work from an accredited program, be licensed or certified by the State, or possess a national credential as a school social work specialist. The term 'State' refers to each of the several States, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. The School-Based Mental Health and Student Service Provider Grant Program is outlined in SEC. 5548. The Secretary will provide grants to eligible States to hire school-based mental health and student service providers. Funds will be allocated to the Secretary of the Interior and outlying areas, as well as to each State based on the number of children in poverty. The Secretary will allocate grants to States based on the number of children in poverty, with a minimum grant amount of $1,000,000. Funds not used by a State will be reallocated to States with approved applications. States must submit an application to receive funding. To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a State must submit an application to the Secretary with a reasonable plan to fund the hiring of school counselors, psychologists, psychiatrists, and social workers. The State must provide a matching amount for grants to local educational agencies to hire school-based mental health and student service providers. The funds can only be used for this purpose and administrative costs are limited to 5 percent. The State must allocate funds for grants to local educational agencies to hire mental health and student service providers, with administrative costs limited to 5 percent. Funds are distributed based on the number of children in poverty in each school district. The State allocates funds for grants to local educational agencies based on the number of children in poverty in each school district. Grants cannot be less than $50,000 and data used must be from the most recent fiscal year. The State uses adjusted data to determine grants for local educational agencies based on child poverty rates. Local agencies must apply for grants and provide matching funds from non-Federal sources. The State may require local educational agencies to match a portion of the grant received, which can be provided in cash or in kind. Funds under this chapter should supplement, not replace, Federal, State, or local funds for school-based mental health services. States must collect data on how the assistance is used and submit a report within one year. The State must report data on the number of mental health professionals employed by local educational agencies and the student to counselor ratios within one year of receiving assistance under this chapter. The State must report data on mental health professionals and student to counselor ratios. Funds can be used for administrative costs. Data received must be made publicly available annually. Authorization of appropriations for grants to improve the mental health of children under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. $100,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2016 to 2024. Amendments made to the table of contents to include grants for school integration and promotion of school readiness.
